questions.text: Which of the following vitamins have a hormonal action?
questions.solution: Vitamin D has hormonal action. In conjunction with parathyroid hormone, it is a major regulatory hormone for Ca2+ and phosphate metabolism.

questions.text: The active form of vitamin D is______
questions.solution:
The active form of Vit D is 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. 

Cholecalciferol is formed in the skin and converted to 25 hydroxycholecalciferol in the liver. This is hydroxylated in the kidney to form 1,25-dihyroxycholecalciferol.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding actions of vitamin D?

choices.text: Vit D receptor-retinoid­ X recep­tor complex binds to DNA and activates tran­scription
Vit D increases absorption of calcium from the intestine by increasing calbindin
Phosphate  flux through the gastrointestinal epithe­lium is enhanced by vitamin D
Vit D decreases phos­phate reabsorption by the renal tubules

questions.solution:
Vit D does not decrease phos­phate reabsorption by the renal tubules. It increases calcium and phos­phate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to a decrease in excretion of these substances in the urine.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with craniotabes, rachitic rosary and bowed legs. Diagnosis of rickets was made. To investigate the cause of rickets and to find the status of vitamin D in the body, which of the following should be measured?
questions.solution:
Measurement of 25 hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) provides more accurate information about vitamin D levels. 

PTH is increased in vitamin D deficiency. PTH is a major stimulus for the 1α-hydroxylase, so there is increased synthesis of the active hormone, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Paradoxically, levels of this hormone are often normal in severe vitamin D deficiency. Therefore, measurements of 1,25- dihydroxyvitamin D are not accurate reflections of vitamin D stores and should not be used to diagnose vitamin D deficiency in patients with normal renal function.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases the conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol?
questions.solution:
The conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is done by enzyme 1α-hydroxylase which is present in the kidney. In chronic renal failure (CRF), there is a deficiency of this enzyme and formation of the active form of vitamin D does not take place.

Factors which increase activity of 1α-hydroxylase are:

  • Ca2+ deficiency
  • Increased parathyroid hormone (PTH)

questions.text: Which organ is not involved in calcium homeostasis?
questions.solution:
The lung is not involved in calcium homeostasis.

There are two sources of cholecalciferol in the body:

  • Diet
  • Synthesized in the skin from 7-dehydrocholesterol in the presence of ultraviolet light.

Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated in the liver to form 25-hydroxycholecalciferol, which is further hydroxylated in the kidney to forn 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. At higher calcium concentrations, when PTH is sup­pressed, the 25-­hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a different compound—24,25­dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect.

Note: This is a controversial question because new evidence suggests an association between calcium homeostasis and pulmonary fibroblasts. Therefore:

  • If Lung is given in the options and spleen is provided as one of the choices instead of Kidneys, Skin, Liver or Intestine, then the best answer would be the spleen.
  • If other options are Kidneys, Skin, Liver, or Intestine, then the best answer would be Lung as the role of these organs in calcium metabolism is beyond doubt.

questions.text: Increased calcium levels lead to______
questions.solution:
Increased calcium levels lead to an increase in 24,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol. 

The levels of calcium control formation of 1,25-dihydroxyxholecalciferol. When calcium is low, PTH (parathyroid hormone) promotes the conversion of 25­hydroxycholecalcif­erol to 1,25­dihydroxycholecalciferol in the kidneys. At higher calcium concentrations, when PTH is sup­pressed, the 25­hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a different compound—24,25­dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect.

questions.text: What would be seen in a patient whose diet is deficient in calcium?
questions.solution:
Low Ca2+ diet leads to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH release. Hence, this patient will have high PTH levels. 

Increased PTH causes

  • Hypophosphatemia due to increased excretion of phosphate via the kidneys.
  • PTH acts on the kidneys to increase the absorption of calcium.
  • PTH also increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D- 1,25 dihydrocholecalciferol.

In the presence of hypocalcemia, serum calcitonin levels decrease and active form of vitamin D increases.

questions.text: In an experiment, a rat is infused with a small volume of a calcium chloride solution. Compared to the control condition, which of the following would result from the calcium load?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, increased formation of 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol will take place.

Infusion of calcium chloride solution will lead to raised calcium concentration in blood. At higher calcium concentrations, PTH is also sup­pressed. So the 25-­hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a different compound : 24,25­dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect.

When plasma calcium concentration is high, formation of 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol is also greatly depressed. Lack of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, in turn, decreases the absorption of calcium from the intestines, bones, and renal tubules, thus causing the calcium ion concentration to fall back toward its normal level.

Option A: Since PTH levels are supressed bone demineralisation does not take place.

Option B: Calcitonin is a calcium regulatory hormone whose level increases when the calcium concentration in plasma is high.

Option C: Calcium ions are a part of the coagulation cascade and the blood coaguability either increases or remains the same with high plasma Ca+2 levels.

questions.text: Calcium absorption takes place mainly from which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Calcium absorption is mainly from the proximal small intestine (duodenum). 

Vit D and PTH are important factors that control calcium absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following is an enhancer of calcium absorption from the intestine?
questions.solution:
Ca 2+ absorption is enhanced by proteins.

It is inhibited by phosphates, phytic acid, and oxalates because these anions form insoluble salts with Ca 2+ in the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the active form of calcium?
questions.solution:
Ionic calcium is the active form that is important for most functions of calcium in the body, including the effect of calcium on the heart, the nervous system, and bone formation. 

Most of the calcium (99%) is stored in the bones. Only about 0.1 percent of the total body calcium is in the extracellular fluid and 1 percent is in the cells and its organelles.

From the 0.1% Ca+2 in the plasma, the distribution of calcium is as follows:  

  • About 41 % is combined with the plasma proteins (non-diffusible through the capillary membrane)
  • About 9 % is combined with anionic substances of the plasma and interstitial fluids like citrate and phosphate in such a manner that it is not ionized (diffusible through the capillary membrane); and
  • The remaining 50 % of the calcium in the plasma is both diffusible through the capillary membrane and ionized.

questions.text: Which of the following cells play a key role in bone resorption?
questions.solution:
Osteoclasts play a key role in bone resorption. 

The cells responsible for bone formation are osteoblasts and the cells responsible for bone resorption are osteoclasts.

Osteoblasts are modified fibroblasts. Osteoclasts are the members of the monocyte family

Osteoclasts erode and absorb the previously formed bone

  • They become attached to the bone via integrins forming a sealing zone where the bone resorption takes place
  • Proton pumps (H+ -ATPases) then move from the endosomes of the osteoclasts into the cell membrane as opposed to the sealing zone and acidify the area to pH 4.0.
  • The acidic pH dissolves hydroxyapatite, and the acid proteases secreted by the cell break down collagen.

questions.text: On infusing parathyroid hormone in experimental mice, there is increased resorption of bone due to stimulation of the osteoclastic activity. Which of the following is true regarding the cellular mechanism of osteoclastic activation?

choices.text: The bone-resorbing osteoclast cells do not have PTH receptors
Osteoclasts produce osteoprotegerin (OPG) a cytokine that increases bone resorption
RANK ligand and M-CSF are necessary for formation of mature osteoblasts
Glucocorticoids promote osteoblast activity and inhibit bone resorption

questions.solution:
Osteoclast cells do not have PTH receptors. PTH stimulates osteoclast activity and bone resorption by an indirect mechanism.

PTH has receptors on the osteoblasts in the bone. When PTH binds to these receptors, osteoblasts release cytokines like RANK-ligand and M-CSF. These cytokines allow the differentiation of macrophages to osteoclasts. 

Osteoclasts, in turn, cut the collagen in the bone, which is bound to calcium. This causes the release of calcium, phosphorus, and collagen breakdown products in the blood. 

Osteoblasts produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), or osteoclastogenesis inhibitory factor, a cytokine that inhibits bone resorption by preventing interaction of RANKL with its receptor. PTH decreases the production of osteoprotegerin (OPG).

Glucocorticoids promote osteoclast activity and increase bone resorption by increasing RANKL production and decreasing the formation of OPG. On the other hand, the hormone estrogen stimulates OPG production.

questions.text: A mouse is engineered to lack a transcription factor necessary for the normal development of osteoclasts. Compared to normal littermate mice, which of the following would be reduced in the knocked-out mouse?
questions.solution:
Secretion of acid proteases would be decreased in the knocked-out mouse. Osteoclasts produce proteolytic enzymes and several acids necessary for bone resorption. The enzymes digest or dissolve the organic matrix of the bone, and the acids cause dissolution of the bone salts.

A knocked-out mouse is a genetically modified mouse in which an existing gene is inactivated or 'knocked out' by replacing it with an artificial one. The control mice used in the above case are littermate mice i.e mice with genetically modified embryonic stem (ES) cell strains used to test whether specific genes control a disease or immunological phenomena (eg: normal osteoclastic development)

Option B: The acidic pH caused by the osteoclasts dissolves hydroxyapatite. In the knocked-out mouse, hydroxyapatite levels would therefore increase. 

Option A and C: Since the lineage of osteoclasts and osteoblasts is different, there is no decrease in the proliferation of osteoblasts. As the osteoblast levels are normal, phosphate deposition in bone also remains normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding calcium homeostasis?

choices.text: 90% of calcium is filtered from the glomerulus
Calcium is reabsorbed mainly from the late distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) promotes calcium reabsorption from the renal tubules
Calcitonin promotes action of parathyroid hormone

questions.solution:
PTH promotes the reabsorption of calcium from the renal tubules. 

Option A: About 41 percent of the plasma calcium is bound to plasma proteins and is therefore not filtered by the glomerular capillaries. The rest of the calcium is filtered through the glomeruli into the renal tubules. 

Option B: Of the filtered calcium, approximately 90 percent is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, loops of Henle, and early distal tubules. However, when calcium levels are low and PTH levels rise, PTH promotes calcium reabsorption from the later DCT. 

Option D: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration and, in general, has effects opposite to those of PTH.

questions.text: Which of the following will be most likely seen in a patient with parathyroid deficiency after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery?

choices.text: High plasma phosphate, low Ca2+ levels and tetanus
Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability, and Trousseau sign
High plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
In a patient with parathyroid deficiency due to inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands, the clinical evaluation will show low Ca+2 level, tetany, trousseau sign, and high phosphate levels. 

PTH is released in response to low calcium levels. It increases the calcium levels by the following actions:

Following signs can be elicited in hypoparathyroidism due to hypocalcemia (tetany): 

  • Chvostek sign: Contraction facial muscles on tapping over facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear
  • Trousseau sign: accoucheur’s hand position and painful carpopedal spasm by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure for 5 minutes

Note - In option A, tetanus is different from tetany. Tetanus is caused by infection with the bacteria Clostridium tetani

questions.text: Which of these cause hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Calcitonin has calcium-lowering effects and may cause hypocalcemia. It does so by inhibiting bone resorption (direct effect)

Calcitonin is synthesized and secreted by parafollicular (clear) cells of the thyroid. Actions of calcitonin are as follows:

  • Inhibits osteoclasts, thereby decreasing bone resorption (direct effect)
  • Increases renal calcium excretion
  • Decreases calcium absorption by the kidneys and intestines

Under normal physiological conditions, calcitonin is more important in young individuals (compared to adults), and it may play a role in skeletal development.

In addition, it may protect the bones of the mother from excess calcium loss during pregnancy. Bone formation in the infant and lactation are major drains on Ca 2+ stores. They would cause bone loss in the mother if bone resorption were not simultaneously inhibited by an increase in the plasma calcitonin level.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady with metastatic breast cancer develops nausea, vomiting and confusion. Further evaluation reveals severe hypercalcemia. IV hydration is initiated and calcitonin is added to her treatment plan. Which of the following best represents the role of calcitonin in lowering serum calcium level?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hypercalcemia of malignancy, most probably due to metastatic breast cancer. Calcitonin exerts its calcium-lowering effect mainly by inhibiting bone resorption and helps in the management of hypercalcemia.

This calcium lowering action of calcitonin is direct, by inhibiting the activity of osteoclasts. However, calcitonin also increases renal calcium excretion and decreases calcium absorption by the kidneys and intestines.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady undergoes thyroidectomy due to suspected malignancy. A week after the surgery she develops a spasm of facial muscles on tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus. Which of the following is the reason behind her muscle hyperexcitability?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chvostek sign, seen in hypocalcemia due to accidental parathyroid injury during thyroid surgery. The muscle hyperexcitability seen in hypocalcemia is due to increased permeability of cells to Na+. 

During thyroid surgery, parathyroid gland is prone to accidental injury due to proximity with the thyroid gland. Damage to the parathyroid gland will lead to a low PTH level and low Ca2+ level. When the ECF concentration of Ca2+ falls below normal, the nervous system becomes progressively more excitable. Because there is increased membrane permeability to Na+. This leads to easy initiation of the action potentials. 

The peripheral nerve fibres become so excitable that they begin to discharge spontaneously, initiating impulses that pass to the skeletal muscles to elicit tetanic muscle contraction. Tetany occurs usually when calcium concentration falls to 6 mg/dL.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding confounders affecting serum calcium level?

choices.text: Total calcium concentration is altered by variations in the serum albumin concentration.
Forearm exercise can lead to falsely elevated ionized calcium levels
Hemoconcentration due to tourniquet results in a rise of serum calcium
Acidosis causes a decrease in the ionized calcium levels

questions.solution:
Acidosis does not cause a decrease in the ionized calcium levels. Rather, alkalosis causes a decrease in the ionized calcium levels.

Plasma proteins are more ionized when the pH is high (alkalosis), providing more protein anions to bind with and sequester free Ca2+. This causes a decrease in ionized calcium and may trigger symptoms of hypocalcemia.

Option A: Total calcium concentration is altered by variations in the serum albumin concentration as 41% of calcium is bound to plasma proteins like albumin, hence changes in albumin concentration affects the serum calcium levels. The corrected calcium levels can be calculated as:

Corrected calcium (mg/dL) = measured total Ca (mg/dL) + 0.8 (4.0 - serum albumin [g/dL]), where 4.0 represents the average albumin level.

Option B: Fist-clenching or forearm exercise can lead to falsely elevated ionized (free) calcium levels.

Option C: A tourniquet is usually avoided while drawing blood for calcium measurements since hemoconcentration also leads to an increase in serum calcium levels.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity?
questions.solution:
Osteoblasts are involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity. 

Osteoblasts produce receptor activator for nuclear factor κ­B ligand (RANKL) and macrophage colony­ stimulating factor (M-CSF), which are necessary for formation of mature osteoclasts and hence osteoclastic activity. 

Specific receptors for parathormone are present only on the osteoblasts and not on osteoclasts.

questions.text: Which of these is not a marker of bone resorption?
questions.solution:
Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase is a marker for bone formation.

Other markers of bone formation are:

  • Serum osteocalcin

  • Serum type 1 procollagen (C-terminal/N-terminal)

Markers for bone resorption are:

  • Urinary hydroxyproline

  • Urinary total pyridinoline (PYD)

  • Urinary free deoxypyridinoline (DPD)

  • Urinary collagen type 1 cross-linked N-Telopeptide(NTX)

  • Urinary or serum collagen type 1 cross-linked C-Telopeptide (CTX)

  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b

International Osteoporosis Foundation has proposed serum CTX and serum PINP (Procollagen 1 N-terminal peptide) to be used as reference markers of bone resorption and formation, respectively, for the assessment of fracture risk and monitoring therapy in clinical settings.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland, which causes primary hyperparathyroidism (not secondary).

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by high levels of parathyroid hormone, to compensate for the low levels of serum calcium, due to some other underlying condition.

Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism, include:

  • Chronic kidney disease: The damaged kidneys are unable to produce sufficient amounts of the active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. This further causes hypocalcemia and triggers PTH secretion.
  • Vitamin D deficiency: Causes hypocalcemia, which triggers the increased secretion of PTH.
  • Lithium: May cause an increased set-point of calcium for parathyroid hormone suppression, which leads to parathyroid hyperplasia.
